Posts.Content: Jun 15, 2008 09:23AM LongHornSurvivor wrote: Lemonpie, thanks for posting the comparison with TAC. I did TAC for Stage III cancer and it was horrible! Should start Gemzar/carbo next week and am hoping for a much smoother ride. (Will have to see if I'm selected for PARP inhibitor.) Let's all hope this combo is our magic bullet. :)
Posts.Title: Gemzar/Carbo zarowny9 FloridaLady

Posts.Content: Aug 14, 2008 08:33AM LongHornSurvivor wrote: Dawn, sorry for falling off the edge of the earth. Been having some challenges with my lungs and the chemo.  Completed two rounds of gemzar/carbo. Have mouth sores, diareahea, fatigue, nausea. Not feverish but feeling like I have the flu today. Funny yesterday, felt like the mouth was clearing up and breathing was getting better. How is Dawn, and anyone else of the regimine doing?
Posts.Title: Gemzar/Carbo zarowny9 FloridaLady

Posts.Content: Jun 21, 2008 06:30AM LongHornSurvivor wrote: Well I don't have the news you're exactly looking for. I was diagnosed triple neg, 1/29/05. Not sure if my tumor size was already at the Stage III size or whether it got there a month or so later when we were really able to image it properly. I was preggars at the time so could only do an ultrasound and small needle biopsy. Only found out about mets this month and they came on fast! Been NED for awhile now. We are going to treat this aggressively so docs a striving for NED again. I know what you are facing is so tough. It's more than OK to get tired of this fight. Hope you can keep finding the spark and inspiration to do what's best, for you. Please let us know how we can help.
Posts.Title: Boost my spirits...long term trip neg mets stories please AlaskaDeb twink

Posts.Content: Jun 18, 2008 01:37AM LongHornSurvivor wrote: Thinking of you!
Posts.Title: Need an angel to ease the pain Monique42 LumiPojo

Posts.Content: Jun 9, 2008 05:56PM LongHornSurvivor wrote: It is always best not to worry until it's time to worry. Hard at first, but after multiple tests, I 've learned that many are routine or a precaution. Just because doctors order serious tests, it means they are trying to rule something OUT, not necessarily expecting a positive results for a disease. Sometimes technicians make comments that they really shouldn't without realizing the effect they may have on the patient. Hope you get the news you are hoping for.
Posts.Title: waiting trip42 LongHornSurvivor

Posts.Content: Jun 21, 2008 02:02PM LongHornSurvivor wrote: Thanks ladies for the encouragement and for acknowledging that this is something to fear. However, the inspiration of strong women here, will help us all. Let's keep giving cancer hell, so that our daughters, nieces, granddaughters, etc. only have to read about metastatic disease as a thing of the past.
Posts.Title: Ready To Hear PET results LongHornSurvivor crazydaisy

Posts.Content: Jun 15, 2008 05:03AM - edited Jun 15, 2008 05:03AM by LongHornSurvivor Thank you kindly ladies for the well wishes and encouragement. Diana, congrats on the news of finishing chemo. Hope you celebrated like crazy. :) Unfortunately the tumor in my lung is cancer and the nodes that lit up are probably the cause of my rib pains. There seems to be a spot on my left hip bone, but the Onc. doesn't think it's necessary to biopsy that. Am going to start a chemo protocol and try the PARP inhibitor if I get selected for it in a clinical trial. Halve already talked with some folks in a local metastatic support group, via telephone. Already lining up my resources to fight this again!
Posts.Title: Ready To Hear PET results LongHornSurvivor crazydaisy

Posts.Content: Jun 7, 2008 11:23PM LongHornSurvivor wrote: Thank you Lumi, and everyone for the well wishes! I hope this Monday morning to get more news about my condition, prognosis and treatment plan. I normally don't ask prognosis numbers, but I will need to have as much information as possible when discussing this with our foster/adoption caseworker. Perhaps I can do short-term care to give other foster parents some time off. If I am expected to remain reasonably healthy, I might advertise for in-home child care. I am listed with the state. Perhaps I can have the experience of caring for someone else's infant while they work. I would love to hear about anyone who has had lung mets in remission for a long time. I wonder if adoption is possible for long term remission?
Posts.Title: parenting question LongHornSurvivor LongHornSurvivor

Posts.Content: Jun 10, 2008 01:47AM - edited Jun 10, 2008 06:38AM by LongHornSurvivor PET: The almost 4 cm lesion in right lung is suspicious for metastasis. There are multiple lymph nodes in the mediastinum are suspcious for metastasis. There's a suspicious lesion on an iliac bone. My oncologist feels there is a chance that the lung lesion could come back as negative for cancer. This pre-biopsy scan is not giving me any comfort. I will have at least one core biopsy in a day and a half. I guess it's not really official until the pathology report comes back. Hope I get lucky this time.
Posts.Title: Ready To Hear PET results LongHornSurvivor crazydaisy

Posts.Content: Jun 19, 2008 11:19PM LongHornSurvivor wrote: Thank you all so much for your inspiration and well wishes. Good to know there are so many brave beautiful women in this world. Well turns out they found a couple of fun happy balls in my brain, so I will have to wait on chemo for the lungs until we finish radiation for my head. Had a couple of treatments already and boy they went much quicker than the previous breast radiation. Guess my brain is fairly small. ;)
